results.description:
Overview

The Trolls games tend to be platformers aimed at smaller children. Presently no new games featuring Troll dolls have been developed since the 1990s.
results.name: Trolls

results.description:
Overview

The Pocket Mine franchise is a series of mining games developed by Roofdog Games for mobile platforms. The first Pocket Mine was originally released in 2013.
results.name: Pocket Mine
Tsuki ni Yorisou Otome no Sahou

results.description:
Overview

Gambler Jiko Chuushinha ("Self-Centered Gambler School") is a series of mahjong console games featuring characters from Masayuki Katayama's manga of the same name. Game Arts, the developers behind the Grandia series, created most of the games based on the license, but other developers like Bits Laboratory and Pack-In-Video were also behind a handful.
results.name: Gambler Jiko Chuushinha

results.description:
Overview

Kingyo Chuuihou! (Goldfish Warning!) is a comedic slice of life manga and anime about Chitose, a rich girl who suddenly loses her fortune, her place in the prestigious Tokai no Gakuen (City Academy) and must enroll in the poor, rural Inaka no Chugakko (Country Jr. High School), which includes barnyard animals among its student body. The manga/anime looks at Chitose's initial culture shock and her eventual attempts to refine her fellow students.

There are three games based on Kingyo Chuuihou: two for the Game Boy and one for the Super Famicom. No games were released outside of Japan. Kingyo Chuuihou characters have occasionally cameo-ed in other video games too.
results.name: Kingyo Chuuihou!

results.description:
Overview

Jinsei Game is the Japanese equivalent of The Game of Life, a board game that allows multiple players to compete to get the best life (as measured by monetary gain). To do this, players move around a board, encountering events that may raise or lower their status, and make occasional decisions with regards to their future livelihoods. Most Jinsei Game adaptations actually begin players at childhood, either in kindergarten or grade school, before they eventually age to maturity and then must navigate the adult world.

Most Jinsei Game adaptations contain the words "Jinsei Game" in their title and have Takara's involvement, usually as a publisher.

The Bakushou!! Jinsei Gekijou games from Taito are considered a separate property, despite also being based on the same board game.
results.name: Jinsei Game

results.description:
Overview

The Grim Legends franchise is a series of hidden object games developed by Artifex Mundi. The series started off with Grim Legends: The Forsaken Bride.
results.name: Grim Legends

results.description:
Overview

A series of visual novels developed and published by Favorite. The games were initially released on the PC but have seen a release on the PlayStation Vita. Japanese illustrator Shida Kazuhiro has worked on all 3 games, contributing the character designs and artwork. The game's scenarios have been written by Urushibara Yukito.

The games consist of

  • Irotoridori no Sekai (Colorful World) The first game in the series. Subtitled Want To Spread My Wings And Fly Into The Sky.
  • Irotoridori no Hikari (Colorful Light) - A sequel or better know as a fandisc for the first game. This features short stories for the sub-heroines and a continuation of the true ending. Subtitled The Eternal Chapter in World's End Tale.
  • Akai Hitomi ni Utsuru Sekai (A World Reflected in Red Eyes) - A sequel set after the fandisc. This continues the true ending story. Subtitled World's End Love Will Last Forever.
results.name: Irotoridori no Sekai

results.description:
Overview

The Double Yakuman games are named for a valuable hand in Japanese rules mahjong, which is what this series focuses on. The first game in the series, March 1993's Double Yakuman, was released on Game Boy. Subsequent games would be released on both the Game Boy and the Super Famicom platforms, with the Super Famicom games adding the "Super" prefix to titles.

There are five games in total:

  • Double Yakuman (Game Boy, 03/19/1993)
  • Double Yakuman Jr. (Game Boy, 08/19/1993)
  • Double Yakuman II (Game Boy, 09/17/1993)
  • Super Double Yakuman (Super Famicom, 04/01/1994)
  • Super Double Yakuman II (Super Famicom, 03/14/1997)
results.name: Double Yakuman

results.description: The Project X Zone series is a series of crossover strategic RPG games developed by Monolith Soft in a collaboration effort with Bandai Namco, Capcom, and Sega. It is a spiritual successor to Namco X Capcom, which was also developed by Monolith Soft.
results.name: Project X Zone

results.description:
Overview

Zero-4 Champ is a series of seven racing games from Media Rings Corporation. The games tend to feature anime-heavy story modes, resembling the anime Initial D and other street-racing franchises, and the races are all straight drag races. The player can buy and modify cars to ensure the fast acceleration needed to win, and the rest depends on the player's skill in switching gears as efficiently as possible.

The series began on the PC Engine in 1991 with the original Zero-4 Champ, with a PC Engine CD sequel in 1993. The next two games were released on the Super Famicom. The series would then move to the Sega Saturn, PlayStation and PlayStation 2.
results.name: Zero-4 Champ

results.description: The player took on the role as a student at the Starfleet or Klingon academies to become a commander of a starship.
results.name: Star Trek: Starfleet Academy

results.description:
Overview

The Didi & Ditto franchise is a series of educational games aimed at younger children.
results.name: Didi & Ditto

results.description:
Overview

Ninja-kun was originally released in 1984 by UPL as an Arcade action game in which the titular diminutive shinobi has to climb and descend a group of platforms to take out every enemy on the stage with their shuriken, which could only be fired left or right. Clearing the stage of enemies would move the player onto the next, and the stages would eventually start recurring similar to other Arcade games like Donkey Kong.

Jaleco ported the game to the Famicom in 1985. UPL would handle the Famicom conversion for their 1987 sequel, Ninja-kun: Ashura no Shou. Since then, the Ninja-kun games have seen a few more adaptations and remakes, and Jaleco would go on to produce the similar Ninja Jajamaru-kun games for various consoles. In US and Europe territories, the Ninja-kun games are known as Ninja-Kid.

Ninja-kun was also referenced by the GameCenter CX/Retro Game Challenge games: their Haggleman character was based on Ninja-kun and Ninja Jajamaru-kun.

The 1983 Ninja-kun game from Microcabin isn't considered part of this series, but is one of the major influences for UPL's 1984 Arcade game. The 1986 NES game Ninja Kid from TOSE/Bandai is not a Ninja-kun game either; rather, it is a graphically-modified Gegege no Kitarou licensed platformer with some similarities.
results.name: Ninja-kun

results.description:
Overview

Hisshou 777 Fighter is a series of pachi-slots games for the Super Famicom. It involves playing a lot of pachi-slots across many machines, earning as much as possible.

The three games include: 1994's Hisshou 777 Fighter: Pachi-Slot Ryugu Densetsu and Hisshou 777 Fighter 2: Pachi-Slot Hi Jouhou, and 1995's Hisshou 777 Fighter III.
results.name: Hisshou 777 Fighter

results.description:
Overview

A post-apocalyptic cyberpunk sci-fi manga and anime that focuses on two ESWAT officers in the utopian city of Olympus: a city-state created after World War 3 destroyed most of the planet's cities and despoiled the environment. It was created by Masamune Shirow. As well as an OVA, three movies (and counting) and a CGI anime series, the franchise also produced several games:

  • Appleseed: Prometheus no Shintaku (1994): A Super Famicom side-scrolling shooter.
  • Appleseed EX (2004): A PS2 action game developed by Sega to coincide with the 2004 CGI movie.
  • Appleseed the Online (2005): An online game for PC. Its servers shut down the following year.
  • Appleseed Tactics (2009): Another online game. Its servers also shut down in the year following its release.
results.name: Appleseed

results.description:
Overview

The "Dead Synchronicity" saga is set in a world on the brink of collapse. A horrible pandemic is turning people into the Dissolved, a condition ending in horrifying death. The cause seems to be a recent event called the Great Wave, comprising a number of natural disasters. An even worse catastrophe is said to be on its way, the eponymous Dead Synchronicity.

Games in the Series

Dead Synchronicity: Tomorrow Comes Today

Michael wakes up in a trailer with no memory of his identity or past events. The chaos surrounding him soon becomes apparent when he starts his quest to find out who he is. Ethics is evidently no longer a concern for most people still alive. Michael might soon have to go against his own morals in order to survive.

Dead Synchronicity: The Longest Night

This is a small text adventure showing the events occurring before the first game in the series. It was first available as a reward to some backers of the Kickstarter campaign for that game, and later to the public.
results.name: Dead Synchronicity

results.description:
Overview

George Tokoro attached his likeness to a number of games which, while often featuring different developers and different genres, feature the same cartoonish art style and a comedic edge.

Tokoro-san no Mamoru mo Semeru mo is an action platformer for the Famicom, released in 1987. Tokoro-san then appeared in a series of mahjong games, including Tokoro's Mahjong for the Super Famicom (released in 1994). Tokoro-san no Setagaya Country Club has Tokoro playing golf. Tokoro-san no Daifugou is a PlayStation board game.
results.name: Tokoro-san

results.description:
Overview

Bonkers was a TV show featuring an anthropomorphic cat that at one time had been a major "toon" movie star, but washed out of Hollywood and decided to join the police force. While dedicated to his police work, Bonkers is still as accident-prone and obsessed with slapstick humor as most toons, and he often creates trouble for his human partner, Lucky Piquel, who often takes the brunt of his hyperactive overeagerness. In later episodes of the show, Lucky was replaced by Miranda Wright, a blonde human cop who is a little more tolerant of Bonkers' antics.

Similar to the situation with the Disney's Aladdin games, Bonkers saw separate Genesis and Super Nintendo games, the former by Sega and the latter by Capcom. It also saw a Game Gear platformer separate from the Genesis game.
results.name: Bonkers

results.description:
Overview

A series of interactive short stories featuring an aspiring art student named Seline. The games were created by Chronerion Entertainment, a small developer studio based in Austria. So far, all of them were made for competitions held by Game Jolt. There was no official name for the franchise when this wiki page was created, why the title of the first game was used. The franchise is however called the "Fragments of Being Her Demise" trilogy now.

Games in the Series

A Fragment of Her

Selina has just moved to the big city in order to start studies at the University of Applied Art. She is thrilled to be accepted by the famous Professor Albert S. Seligmann, but soon realize he is not what she expected.

Being Her Darkest Friend

In what seems like a dream of horrors, Selina is haunted by what happened in the first game.

Ceasing to be Her Demise

Selina thought she had gotten rid of her nightmares, but they are back and even worse than before.
results.name: A Fragment of Her
The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing

results.description:
Overview

Flash Gordon began as a comic strip in the 1930s originally created to rival the growing success of the Buck Rogers comic strip.

Films

Flash Gordon (1980)

A feature film based on Flash Gordon, directed by Mike Hodges, was released in 1980. It was an Anglo-Italian production helmed by Dino De Laurentiis. Flash Gordon is perhaps best known for its soundtrack performed by the British rock group Queen, as well as the infamous line "Gordon's alive?" spoken by Brian Blessed's character Prince Vultan.

Trivia

  • Originally, George Lucas requested to direct a feature-length Flash Gordon film but was rejected. He would later use the Flash Gordon film serials as a basis for the creation of the Star Wars franchise.
results.name: Flash Gordon
